SKILL_NAME: Identify the author's purpose (e.g., to inform, describe, entertain, explain, share feelings)

Analyze and critique how the author's use of language, organizational structures, techniques, and rhetorical devices further or detract from the author's purpose or viewpoint

SKILL_NAME: Combine a vowel and a consonant sound to produce a single syllable
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Blend grade-appropriate words with a greater number of phonemes, including consonant blends and consonant digraphs (e.g., slide, whisper, branch)
AUTHORITY: Indiana Academic Standards for English/Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Decode by sounding and blending, phoneme by phoneme, regular words including words with adjacent consonants (e.g., CVCC words w-e-n-t, d-e-s-k and CCVC words t-r-i-p, s-t-o-p)
Create new syllables by orally blending unfamiliar consonants with familar vowels (e.g., blend the phonemes /n/-/a/ to make the first syllable in nada and /j/-/o/ to make the second syllable in rojo)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Segment grade-appropriate words with four or five phonemes, including words with digraphs and blends (e.g., identify the sounds /sh/ /i/ /p/ /s/ in ships)
With support, begin to blend onsets and rimes to form familiar single-syllable words (e.g., blend the sounds /p/ /an/ to pronounce pan)
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Blend phonemes, including consonant blends, to pronounce two-syllable and three-syllable words (e.g., blend the sounds /blu/ /sa/ to produce blusa; blend /ha/ /bla/ /do/) to produce hablado
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify and pronounce single-syllable words by blending and segmenting consonant blends, long vowel digraphs, and other phonemes (e.g., identify the sounds /th/ /r/ /ee/ in three and blend the sound /th/ /r/ /ee/ to produce three)
Participate in teacher-led oral sounding and blending of CVC words (e.g., "Where is the c-a-t?" "This is my p-e-n.")
Decode words consisting of two or more syllables that contain taught graphemes (e.g., container, pavement, supermarket)
Decode by blending, phoneme by phoneme, a wider range of three-letter CVC words made from grapheme-phoneme correspondences that have been taught (e.g., l-e-g, r-u-n, p-o-t)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Segment grade-appropriate words, including those with consonant digraphs and consonant blends, into their component phonemes (e.g., shop, blocks)
AUTHORITY: Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Blend grade-appropriate words with four or five phonemes, including words with digraphs and blends (e.g., blend the sounds /sh/ /i/ /p/ /s/ to produce ships)
Blend phonemes orally to produce words (e.g., blend the sounds /b/ /u/ /g/ to produce bug) and segment and count the sounds in words
Recognize consonant combinations (consonant + l; consonant + r) in familiar words that contain liquid letters (e.g., blanco, planta, grande, tronco, traspaso, claro, trabajo, otra, cuatro)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify, blend, and segment onsets and rimes in multisyllabic words (e.g., blend the sounds /p/ /ic/ /n/ /ic/ to produce picnic)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify and blend onsets and rimes in single-syllable words (e.g., identify the sounds /m/ /an/ in man and blend the sounds /m/ /an/ to produce man)
Segment onsets and rimes in single-syllable words (e.g., segment man into the sounds /m/ /an/)
With support, begin to segment onsets and rimes in single-syllable words (e.g., segment can into the sounds /c/ /an/)
Decode a range of words of more than one syllable that contain taught grapheme-phoneme correspondences by blending, phoneme by phoneme, throughout the word (e.g., s-i-ng-i-ng, t-oo-th-b-r-u-sh)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Blend phonemes, including consonant blends, to pronounce single-syllable words (e.g., es, me, tren, sin, flan, gran, son)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Segment onsets and rimes in single-syllable spoken words, including words with blends, digraphs, and trigraphs (e.g., segment spring into the sounds /spr/ /ing/)
AUTHORITY: Georgia K-12 English Language Arts Standards

SKILL_NAME: With support, understand that two syllables can be combined to make a single word (e.g., /mo/ /no/ = mono)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Read words that are not already familiar but that contain taught GPCs by blending, phoneme by phoneme, throughout the word (e.g., t-r-a-ck, th-r-u-sh)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Decode, by blending phoneme by phoneme, throughout the word, a variety of words containing a common taught grapheme which may be pronounced differently in each word (e.g., the letter y maps to the phoneme /i:/ in the word happy, the phoneme /aı/ in the word sky, the phoneme /j/ in the word yes)
AUTHORITY: North Dakota English Language Arts Content Standards

SKILL_NAME: Segment single-syllable words, including those with blends and digraphs, into their component phonemes in sequence (e.g., segment glad into the sounds /g/ /l/ /a/ /d/)

Decode, by blending phoneme by phoneme, throughout the word, a variety of words with common phonemes that are represented by different graphemes that have been taught (e.g., in some accents, pour, poor, pore; tie, high)
Blend phonemes, including consonant blends, to pronounce two-syllable words (e.g., blend the sounds /fl/ /ow/ - /er/ to produce flower)
Divide two-syllable CVCV words into their component syllables (e.g., me-sa, ca-ma, ca-sa, pe-ro, ga-to)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify VC, CVC, CVCC, and CCVC words by blending phonemes including consonant blends (e.g., identify the word spin by blending the sounds /sp/ /i/ /n/)
Blend phonemes, including blends and digraphs, to pronounce single-syllable words (e.g., blend the sounds /sl/ /e/ /d/ to produce sled)
Blend onsets and rimes in single-syllable spoken words, including words with blends, digraphs, and trigraphs (e.g., blend the sounds /spr/ /ing/ to produce spring)
AUTHORITY: Georgia K-12 English Language Arts Standards

SKILL_NAME: Use dashes to indicate a pause, break, or emphasis
Analyze how an informational text presents cause-and-effect relationships, recognizing faulty cause-and-effect descriptions
Infer implied cause-and-effect relationships from specific information in a historical, scientific, or technical text
Explain cause-and-effect relationships (i.e., explain what happened and why) in a literary text by comprehending specific information in the plot as well as by identifying individual cue words
With prompting and support, demonstrate understanding that some events lead to other events and that actions have consequences and/or reactions
When reading historical, scientific, and technical texts, describe how some events lead to other events and how actions have consequences/reactions
Analyze the cause-and-effect interactions between individuals, events, and ideas in an informational text (e.g., analyze how ideas influence an individual)
Identify and describe cause-and-effect relationships in texts by recognizing words and clauses that signal those relationships (e.g., because, so)
With prompting and support, identify a directly stated cause of an event discussed in an informational text
Analyze in detail how the causal relationships between individuals, events, and ideas are introduced and developed in an informational text
Identify directly stated causes and effects in an informational text (e.g., describe what makes an event happen)
Analyze implied or subtly stated cause-and-effect relationships in a literary text and understand that a preceding event does not necessarily mean it is the cause of the next event
Identify and describe comparisons indicated by clauses beginning with words such as pero and sin embargo in informational texts
Apply knowledge from the text and from prior experience to predict likely effects of a cause or to infer the cause of effects in a literary text
Infer implied causes and effects in a literary text
Analyze events and trace them back to their causes through a series of events in an informational text
Identify cause-and-effect relationships with multiple causes and/or effects in literary texts and recognize chain reactions of events
Analyze contributing factors and degrees of influence among cause-and-effect relationships in informational texts

Explain cause-and-effect relationships (i.e., explain what happened and why) in a historical, scientific, or technical text by comprehending specific information in the text as well as by identifying individual cue words
Evaluate the credibility of the characters and plot in a work of fiction by comparing them to prior experience
Describe character relationships and understand their importance to the plot of a story
Understand nonchronological narration (e.g., a novel or play in which the outcome is told at the beginning) and analyze how it affects the plot
Compare and contrast characters using specific details and describe how they interact with other characters
Analyze differences in characters' moral dilemmas in works of fiction across countries and cultures
With prompting and support, begin to link events in a story to personal experience (e.g., "I play in the park sometimes.")
With prompting and support, begin to anticipate some events in a story, using pictures (e.g., "Yes, it does look like he might slip in that puddle.")
Analyze plot structure and development, including how conflicts are resolved (e.g., how particular lines of dialogue and events propel the action or reveal character)

Describe the development of the plot, in particular how plot unfolds in a series of events or episodes (e.g., exposition and character development, rising action and falling action, turning point and climax, conflict and resolution)
With prompting and support, identify and retell major events including beginning, middle, and end of a story
Compare and contrast key events in the plot of a story or drama (e.g., compare how a character acts when facing similar circumstances)
Analyze the moral dilemmas presented in works of fiction as revealed by the underlying motivations, behaviors, and decisions of characters
Compare and contrast complex characters (e.g., multidimensional characters with conflicting motivations) within and between texts
AUTHORITY: Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Evaluate whether the plot of a story is believable
Evaluate the credibility of the characters and plot in a work of fiction by providing specific details from the text as evidence
Identify archetypal traits in characters (e.g., the hero on a quest)

Analyze and evaluate the author's development of characters and other literary elements in light of genre and the author's intent (e.g., whether the character's psychological depth and complexity reflect the level of realism in a novel or whether a relatively simple characterization is appropriate in a comedy)
Critique the significance and validity of the author's plot choices, including sequence of events (e.g., in giving insight to the meaning, theme, or message), and evaluate these choices
Explain how different types of characters in a story (e.g., static, dynamic, protagonist, antagonist) influence the plot
With prompting and support, begin to anticipate some events in a story, using pictures (e.g., "Sí, parece que se podría caer en el charco.")
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Discuss how social, moral, or cultural issues or themes in stories drive the plot (e.g., how the justice system is portrayed in <i>Holes</i?; why the boy in a story goes to live in the wilderness)
Analyze characters' depth (e.g., static vs. dynamic; flat vs. round) and how character development affects the plot or shapes the theme
Analyze how actions and events in the plot influence other story elements (e.g., how events shape characters)
Analyze the main character's motive and point of view, including how these affect other characters and help shape the plot
Describe a character, the main character's interactions with other characters, and the relationship between a character's actions, traits, and motives
Describe main story events (e.g., "Juegan en el parque.")
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Describe characters including their traits, motives, and feelings
Apply knowledge of characters from different genres to identify and discuss character types (e.g., villains, victims, heroes)
Explain how characters are revealed through their thoughts and actions, through the thoughts of other characters, through dialogue, and through the author's descriptions
Describe how the events in the plot build on one another including how the conflict is created and resolved
Describe major events in a story using key details from the text
Analyze the development of complex characters over the course of the narrative and how they influence the narrative (e.g., advance the plot or refine the theme; interact with other characters)
Describe characters using key details
Analyze how characters' actions influence the plot and how events advance the plot
Compare and contrast characters including their roles in the plot
Analyze how authors reveal character (e.g., thoughts, dialogue, dialect)
Discuss the title of a story in relation to the events (e.g., "It's called Molly's Surprise because her grandma brought her a surprise.")
With prompting and support after listening to a story, think of other ways it could end (e.g., what else could Joey have done?)
Evaluate the quality of a literary work and the characters' portrayal especially when affected by the author's underlying philosophy

Begin to explore how the author has developed characters through dialogue, action, description, and relationship to other characters (e.g., "The author shows the soldier is nervous through the way he keeps pausing when he talks to the king.")
Analyze characters' traits, responses, and motives and how the central character influences the plot or theme
With support, identify character relationships (e.g., sisters, friends)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Analyze development of characters as revealed through different means such as the use of narration, dialogue, archetypes, and character foils, and analyze the impact of the author's choices about characters such as how to introduce or develop them
Analyze internal and external character responses and how these affect the plot
Identify the basic elements of a story's plot (e.g., problem, important events)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Discuss main story events and simple reasons for, or causes of, events (e.g., "He slipped because the floor was wet.")
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Describe how characters respond to major events and challenges (e.g., how does the character solve the problem?)
Describe main story events (e.g., "They play in the park.")
Analyze how and why characters change and respond as the plot develops
Identify a story's problem and its resolution (e.g., why is Helen unhappy? How does Ben find his dog?)
Explain how characters' motives and actions contribute to the sequence of events
Analyze the underlying archetypal forces and motivations behind the plot (e.g., blindness in Marianela)
Recognize that characters are revealed through their thoughts and actions, through the thoughts of other characters, through dialogue, and through the author's descriptions
Analyze crucial moments in the plot (e.g., complication, climax, sea change) and explain how they advance the plot or develop the theme
Identify a story's problem and its resolution (e.g., ¿Por qué María está triste? ¿Qué hace Javier para encontrar a su perro?)
Analyze the underlying archetypal forces and motivations behind the plot (e.g., the storm in "King Lear")
Describe the changes that characters undergo as the plot develops
Describe plot elements and structure (e.g., exposition, conflict, and resolution), and explain how key events advance the plot and can foreshadow later events of a story or drama
Identify directly stated causes and effects in a literary text (e.g., describe what makes an event happen or a character act a certain way)
Begin to identify social, moral, or cultural issues in stories that influence the plot (e.g., "The lion is in charge and makes the decisions.")

Analyze how the author's plot choices give insight to the meaning, theme, or message of the text (e.g., If the author had made a different choice, how would that choice have affected the plot? Does that reveal the significance of the author's choice?)
Recognize how characters change in a story
Describe plot elements and trace how events and characters' actions contribute to the plot (e.g., lead to the resolution of a problem)
Analyze how characters' actions, thoughts, motivations, and relationships shape the plot
Critique literary works; analyze and evaluate how structural choices and plot devices advance the plot and affect the meaning and impact of a work of fiction on the reader
Analyze characters and their interactions with other characters and with other literary elements (e.g., how character relationships advance the plot or reveal the theme)

Analyze plot structure and development (e.g., conflict and resolution, rising and falling action, subplots) and determine how events advance the plot, explain previous events, and foreshadow later events
Analyze how complex characters and character relationships develop and change in a text and how this advances the plot or theme of the work
Evaluate the credibility and consistency of the characters and plot and whether this affects the quality of the text
Analyze characters' depth and contribution to the narrative, and evaluate whether the characters' portrayal affects the quality of a literary work
Understand the influence of the setting and the characters on the plot
Analyze a particular scene or section of a story and how it affects the whole
Describe how events in a literary text lead to other events and how actions have consequences/reactions
Determine the type of conflict present in a story (e.g., person vs. person/self/nature)
Give the reasons for a character's actions (e.g., why did she do that?)
With support, identify characters in a story read aloud

Identify the main idea of literary texts (i.e., answer the question, "What is this book about?")
Determine the central idea of an informational text and explain how it is conveyed with details
Retell key details of an informational text
Understand that details support the main idea in an informational passage
Analyze how similar central ideas develop across informational texts from various time periods, places, and/or cultures, including speeches and essays
AUTHORITY: Indiana Academic Standards for English/Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify how language, author's intent, and structure are used to develop and support the main ideas and themes in informational texts
AUTHORITY: North Dakota English Language Arts Content Standards

SKILL_NAME: Identify main ideas that are directly stated or strongly implied
Distinguish the main idea from the main topic in an informational text
Identify and explain the main idea of an informational text and explain how key details support it
Analyze the development of the central idea or thesis of an informational text and how it relates to supporting ideas and details
Distinguish more important from less important details in literary texts
Identify the author's main idea and purpose in a literary text
Provide a complex analysis of how multiple central ideas develop in an informational text and how these ideas work together
Analyze and apply information in real-world forms and technical documents, and summarize their main ideas and purpose
AUTHORITY: English Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish more important from less important details in an informational text
Analyze the development of the central idea over the course of an informational text and how details support or clarify it
Identify directly stated main ideas and important details
Analyze the development of multiple central ideas in an informational text
Identify the topic of simple informational texts, using pictures, front cover, and title (e.g., "This book is about cats.")
With support, find and record or note (e.g., underline, take notes) the main idea of a section of text, along with key words, phrases, or sentences relating to a specific topic
With prompting and support, retell key details of an informational text
Describe the key details of an informational text and explain how they support the main idea
Identify the main topic of an informational text
With prompting and support, identify the main topic of an informational text
Distinguish main idea from topic
Identify the topic of an informational text as a whole and identify the subtopics of paragraphs
Evaluate and critique how similar central ideas develop across informational texts from different time periods, places, and/or cultures, including historic speeches and essays
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Integrate a literary text's visual and written components to deepen understanding of the text's meaning and themes (e.g., explain how the illustrations in an illustrated novel help convey the mood)

Explain how specific images contribute to and clarify the information in a text (e.g., how an image of the earth next to the sun adds to what the text says about the relative sizes of the earth and the sun)
Analyze how media informs, persuades, interprets events, and influences culture
Identify a variety of written conventions used in digital media (e.g., websites, emails, video games)
Draw on multiple print or digital sources to quickly and efficiently obtain specific information relevant to answering a question or solving a problem
Evaluate how media messages present views in ways that differ from those of other texts
Make connections between a print text and an audio, video, or live version of the text
Analyze multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem, critiquing how each version interprets the source text and uses departures from the text to create new messages and meanings

Analyze how visual and other multimedia elements contribute to the meaning, tone, or beauty of a literary text (e.g., describe how the illustrations in a book or graphic novel help you understand the setting)
Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums, evaluating each account's use of particular details and interpretation of the subject

Interpret information presented visually, orally, or quantitatively (e.g., in charts, graphs, diagrams, timelines, animations, or interactive online text features) and explain how the information contributes to deeper understanding of the text's topic
Understand the meaning of text via multiple mediums (e.g., written, visual, audio, video)
Describe instances in which a performance is different from the written text of a story or drama
Compare different forms of media and explain how they present information in different ways (e.g., web, newspapers, documentaries)
Analyze and explain how the medium used impacts the presentation of information
Explain how media messages are conveyed (e.g., a song used to advertise a product)
Describe the structural and substantive differences between an autobiography or diary and a fictional adaptation of it
Compare techniques used in media (e.g., Internet vs. television advertising) and how they influence the message and viewer
Look at and talk about illustrations and print in nonfiction books and print in the environment
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Recognize the role of the media in informing people and influencing their opinions
Locate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different mediums or formats and integrate and apply the information in order to address a question or solve a problem
Analyze various accounts of a subject told in different mediums, recognizing the particular contribution of each medium in conveying information on the topic
With support, tell what is happening in an illustration or picture
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Compare and analyze the effectiveness of techniques used in a variety of digital texts and sources (e.g., embedded video and links, sensational headlines, allowing comments) to deepen understanding of their use and influence on message and audience
Analyze what effects media may have on elections and public attitudes, and evaluate effectiveness of media messages
Recognize similarities between a print text and an audio, video, or live version of the text (e.g., note that the same story is being told)

Compare and contrast how information on the same topic is presented in different mediums (e.g., how a film of Martin Luther King's "Tengo un sueño" speech captures its emotional impact while a written description of it provides important contextual information; or the distinct versions of Eva Perón's "No llores por mi Argentina" speech on the balcony of the Casa Rosada)

Compare and contrast reading the text of a story, drama, or poem to listening or viewing a performed version, describing how each version affects the reader or viewer (e.g., explain whether the suspense is greater in the written or performed version of the text)
Explain how the presentation of information in a text contributes to or detracts from the clarity and effectiveness of its message
Explain how different media are made for different reasons (e.g., movies tell a story; newspapers inform about events; ads persuade people to buy things)
Explain how simple design techniques used in media (e.g., color, text, images) influence the message and viewer
Interpret common types of visually presented information (e.g., maps, photographs, graphs, information tables)
With support, explain how media messages are conveyed (e.g., television ad uses music and video to sell a product)

Compare and contrast two interpretations of a story, poem, or drama (e.g., a live production of Hamlet to a filmed version of it), analyzing the effects and implications of the different decisions the directors and performers make
Analyze how media may manipulate visual and verbal messages (e.g., include or exclude information) to achieve certain purposes (e.g., create an emotional response; advance a point of view)
Recognize similarities and differences between a print text and an audio, video, or live version of the text
Make connections between a written literary text and a visual or oral presentation of the text
Describe a story's elements and key details (e.g., characters and their actions and emotions, the setting, moments in the plot) based on information provided by the story's illustrations and words
Understand the meaning of text via multiple mediums including multimedia presentations (e.g., interactive educational computer games)
With prompting and support, describe how illustrations relate to the information in a text
Compare and contrast visual and verbal messages in various media, recognizing their separate influences (e.g., whether the visuals convey ideas not included in the text)
Analyze how differences in perspective (e.g., differences in age, cultural background, values) influence how people experience media messages differently
Look at and talk about illustrations and print in fiction books and print in the environment
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Analyze and compare the tone of various digital media sources (e.g., levels of formality and informality in websites, instructional videos)

Analyze how the medium used contributes to the message conveyed in a filmed, performed, or multimedia version of a literary text (e.g., explain how a film director can emphasize the beauty of a natural setting by focusing on landscape and sound)
Interpret and analyze data presented in multiple graphical sources
With prompting and support, talk through the events in picture story books, making comments about what can be seen in the pictures
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Evaluate how text, audio, and images interact in various media to communicate ideas, and recognize how these messages are crafted by design (e.g., images could present contradictory ideas to manipulate the meaning of a verbal message or to create irony)
Analyze media presentations to identify the points of view or messages they convey (e.g., what values or ideas are promoted?; what perspectives are left out?)
With prompting and support, talk through the content of illustrations and diagrams in informational texts

Compare and contrast the written text of a story, drama, or poem to a performed version of it, analyzing differences and the effects of techniques unique to the medium of the performance (e.g., describe how a filmmaker conveys a scary mood through lighting and sound whereas an author would do this through word choice)

Compare and contrast two interpretations of a story, poem, or drama (e.g., the book El beso de la mujer araña de Manuel Puig to a filmed version of it), analyzing the effects and implications of the different decisions the directors and performers make
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Apply and integrate ideas and information from illustrations and multimedia elements, interpret their meaning and perspective, and evaluate them for accuracy, credibility, and relevance
AUTHORITY: Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Analyze the representation of a subject, event, key scene, or story in two different mediums, describing the significance of what is emphasized or absent in each treatment
Analyze how media messages include or exclude points of view and can influence beliefs, behaviors, and interpretations
Synthesize information from multiple graphical sources (e.g., maps, charts, diagrams) to draw conclusions about the ideas presented
Evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of using different mediums to present a particular topic
With prompting and support, describe how illustrations relate to the story in which they appear
Identify and apply information from illustrations outside the text to deepen understanding of a topic or answer a question relevant to the text
Begin to use role-play to explore familiar stories and characters
Analyze and evaluate the choices made by directors, performers, and artists in departing from and interpreting the written text or script (e.g., explain differences in what each version emphasizes)
Analyze how media influences public perception and opinion

Select the appropriate source of information when seeking answers to a question or solving a problem (e.g., refer to an atlas and find the correct map to confirm which countries the equator runs through)

Compare and contrast how information on the same topic is presented in different mediums (e.g., how a film of Martin Luther King's "I Have a Dream" speech captures its emotional impact while a written description of it provides important contextual information)
Analyze and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in different formats and apply findings toward answering discipline-specific questions and solving problems

Compare and contrast multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem, analyzing and evaluating how each version interprets the source text (e.g., discuss the similarities and differences between Kenneth Branagh's and Franco Zeffirelli's interpretations of Hamlet)
Recognize and use basic types of illustrations found in informational texts (e.g., diagrams, pictures reflecting the narrative) for clarification or to answer questions
Describe how a visual or oral presentation of a story or drama reflects the text (e.g., the actor shouts because the stage directions call for it)
Explain how a text's illustrations reflect and contribute to the story (e.g., describe actions, create mood, emphasize aspects of a character or setting)
Recognize the characteristics of various media messages
Identify elements of a multimedia product that are unique to that medium (e.g., lighting and sound in a film) and explain the intended effect on the audience
With support, identify how media messages are conveyed (e.g., television ad has sound and pictures)
Explain how language and visual effects convey a point of view or impact an audience (e.g., attract their attention)
Interpret the changing role of the media over time and its influence on public opinion
With support, reenact familiar stories, showing some awareness of characters' feelings (e.g., Cinderella's feelings before and after the ball)

Compare and contrast how the same subject, theme, key scene, or story is treated in different mediums (e.g., describe the differences between how a story from mythology is told in an epic poem and represented in a classical painting)
Identify the target audiences of media messages (e.g., infer the target audience of an ad based on where it is placed and when it runs)

Analyze how an author is inspired by and transforms the original material of a specific work (e.g., how Cervantes draws on a theme from the text of Cid Campeador or of Greco-Latin mythology, or how a later author, such as Jorge Luis Borges, is based on Don Quixote by Cervantes)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Describe the person, place, idea, or thing depicted by an informational text graphic

Interpret visual and other multimedia elements (e.g., illustrations, real or fictional maps, sound tracks) to confirm details and deepen understanding of a story (e.g., refer to a fictional map to get a sense of the length of a hero's journey)
Integrate visual, quantitative, and written information to develop a coherent explanation of a topic or issue (e.g., read source material to gather information for a research topic)
Analyze the changing role of the media over time
With support, tell what an author and illustrator contribute to a text
Understand the meaning of text in commonly encountered grade-appropriate media (e.g., written, visual, audio, video)

Compare and contrast multiple interpretations of a story, drama, or poem, analyzing and evaluating how each version interprets the source text (e.g., discuss the similarities and differences between El ingenioso hidalgo don Quijote de la Mancha by Cervantes and the movie Un Hombre de la Mancha by Arthur HIller)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Describe elements of a story (e.g., characters, setting, events) based on information provided by both its illustrations and words
Use information from the illustrations and words in an informational text to comprehend its key details
Use information in illustrations to find key details and deepen understanding of the text
Identify persuasive strategies used by media and analyze the possible effects on readers or viewers
Explain, citing textual details, how visually presented information (e.g., illustrations, charts, graphs, timelines, animations) supports a text's central idea or claim
AUTHORITY: New Jersey Student Learning Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Use the correct homophones (e.g., feat/feet), homographs (e.g., estimate, conflict), and multiple-meaning words (e.g., chief) in writing and speaking and determine their correct meanings in grade-appropriate texts

AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Determine the meanings of homographs/multiple-meaning words (e.g., hoja (of a plant) and hoja (of paper)) in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings

SKILL_NAME: Identify and use homographs/multiple-meaning words (e.g., amo (verb) and amo (owner) and determine their meanings in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings

SKILL_NAME: Determine or clarify the meaning of homonyms in a fourth-grade text
Identify and use homophones (e.g., vello/bello) and determine their meanings in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Determine the correct meanings of homophones (e.g., ascent/assent; gild/guild), homographs (e.g., articulate, attribute), and multiple-meaning words within context in grade-appropriate texts and use them correctly in writing and speaking
Identify and use multiple-meaning words (e.g., burro: animal, y burro: an insult) and determine their meanings in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Determine the correct meaning of homophones using context clues (e.g., as, has y haz) and homographs/multiple-meaning words (e.g., cuenta (realize), cuenta (verb), and cuenta (the bill)) in grade-appropriate texts
Determine or clarify the meaning of homographs in a fifth-grade text
Use homophones accurately based on fourth-grade reading and content

Use the correct homophones (e.g., revelar and rebelar) and homographs/multiple meaning words (e.g., violar (violate) and violar (break, infringe), and determine their correct meanings in grade-appropriate texts
Determine the meanings of homophones (e.g., hola and ola) in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Determine or clarify the meaning of homographs in a second-grade text

Use the correct homophones (e.g., bow/beau), and use context clues to determine the meanings of homographs (e.g., initial, quarry, couch) and multiple-meaning words (e.g., canteen) in writing and speaking and determine their correct meanings in grade-appropriate texts
Explain the differences between commonly confused terms (e.g., porque/porqué/por qué/por que; asimismo (adverbio) / así mismo (de la misma manera); sino/si no, and también/tan bien)

SKILL_NAME: Determine the meanings of homophones (e.g., to/two, ant/aunt, be/bee) and homographs/multiple-meaning words (e.g., bark, bat, fly) in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings
Determine or clarify the meaning of homographs in a fourth-grade text

Determine or clarify the meaning of homonyms in a second-grade text

Use the correct homophones (e.g., siervo/ciervo) and homographs/multiple-meaning words (e.g., sal (verb) vs. sal (ingredient in food); cura (cure) vs. cura (priest); cara (part of the head) vs. cara (expensive)) in writing and speaking and determine their correct meanings in grade-appropriate texts

Identify and correctly use homographs/multiple-meaning words (e.g., cerca (verb) and cerca (fence), nada (verb) and nada (nothing)) and determine their meanings in grade-appropriate texts using sentence context or prior knowledge of spellings

SKILL_NAME: Change spoken multisyllable words by deleting or substituting phonemes to make new words (e.g., substitute /p/ with /v/ in open to make oven)
Use knowledge of ending sounds to match sounds in written words (e.g., select the word that has the /oso/ ending sound from the choices hermoso, rosa, temblar)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Delete initial and final sounds in one-syllable words to make new words (e.g., delete the /sk/ and the final /s/ from skates to make ate)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Separate and pronounce phonemes, like initial or medial vowels or final sounds, in monosyllabic words produced orally
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: With support, understand that two phonemes can be combined to create a syllable (e.g., /m/ /o/ = /mo/)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Combine two or three phonemes to make words that make sense (e.g., la, las, un, una, uno)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: With support, recognize and match sounds in spoken words
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Begin to distinguish between different sounds and phonemes in spoken words, including initial and final sounds
Recognize, identify, and produce groups of words that begin with the same initial sound (i.e., alliterative words, tongue twisters)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Rapidly identify correct letter-sound correspondences, including letters that can represent more than one sound
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Decode and encode grade-appropriate words with special letter combinations (e.g., q is always used with u)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify, match, and distinguish consonant blends
Match sounds in words by finding the objects in a picture with the same beginning sound
Decode multisyllabic nonsense words to demonstrate basic phonics skills and knowledge of a variety of spelling patterns
AUTHORITY: Georgia K-12 English Language Arts Standards

SKILL_NAME: Isolate, say, and distinguish initial or final phonemes in spoken CVC words (e.g., say the initial sound in hat, the final sound in cup)
Isolate and pronounce each sound in grade-appropriate words including those with consonant digraphs and consonant blends (e.g., what is the ending sound in finish?)
AUTHORITY: Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Engage in wordplay by substituting sounds in words to invent new words (e.g., button/tubbon)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Understand that switching, deleting, or adding letters changes a word (e.g., loro to coro; mesa to mes; andar to mandar)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Isolate and then pronounce the initial, medial, or final sound in single-syllable words including those with long vowels and consonant blends (e.g., what is the middle sound in goat?)
With support, identify the sounds made by consonant and vowel digraphs (e.g., ch, th, sh, wh, ph, ck; ai, ee, ea, ie, oo, ow)
AUTHORITY: National curriculum in England: English programmes of study

SKILL_NAME: Understand that changing or adding a letter changes a word (e.g., pick which word is made from -at when reading the words rat, rap, and run; pick which word is made when adding r to band when reading the words brand, bread, and bring; pick which word is made when adding t to the end of star when reading the words spark, start, and tears)
Combine a vowel and a consonant sound to produce a CV syllable
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Decode and encode grade-appropriate words with unusual or less-familiar letter combinations and special situations (e.g., qu in quiet; gh in laugh and ghost; the similar sound in axe and picks)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Change phonemes to show addition, deletion, substitution, reversal, or resequencing of sounds in words or blends
Isolate and say long vowel sounds in single-syllable words in spoken language
Decode and encode grade-appropriate words with special or less-familiar letter combinations (e.g., qu in quack, gh in laugh)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Decode one-syllable nonsense words with a variety of common spelling patterns
AUTHORITY: Georgia K-12 English Language Arts Standards

SKILL_NAME: Recognize all common graphemes representing the phonemes in the English language when decoding words
Isolate sounds in grade-appropriate words with four to five phonemes (e.g., baby, river, seven)
Add or substitute initial, final, or medial vowel phonemes in order to produce new words in spoken language (e.g., change /a/ final en casa to /o/ to make caso)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Add or substitute initial or final phonemes in order to produce new one-syllable words in spoken language (e.g., change the /k/ in cat to /h/ to make hat; change the /g/ in bug to /s/ to make bus)

Respond with the correct phoneme to a wider range of graphemes where two letters represent one consonant sound (digraphs) (e.g., respond with the phoneme /ʃ/ to the grapheme sh in the word ship; respond with the phoneme /tʃ/ to the grapheme ch in the word chop; respond with the phoneme /θ/ to the grapheme th in the word thin)
With support, substitute initial sounds in words to make new words (e.g., hat/cat)
AUTHORITY: Georgia K-12 English Language Arts Standards

SKILL_NAME: Isolate, say, and distinguish initial or final phonemes in spoken CVC words (e.g., say the initial sound in pon, the final sound in las)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Delete individual sounds in simple, one-syllable words to make new words (e.g., delete the /h/ from hair to make air)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Recognize that a syllable can consist of a single vowel (e.g., a-mo; mí-o; dí-a; vi-ví-a; a-brí-a; o-jo; u-ña; e-so)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Isolate and distinguish short vowel sounds in single-syllable words in spoken language (e.g., from a verbal prompt, identify that hat has a different middle vowel sound than hit)
With support, recognize which segment of a word is left off when spoken aloud (e.g., recognize that the /p/ is left off when “icnic” is spoken)
Count phonemes in single-syllable words
Substitute medial vowels in written single-syllable words
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Add or substitute initial, final, or medial vowel phonemes in order to produce new words in spoken language (e.g., change /a/ in pan to /e/ to make pen)

Substitute initial or final phonemes in order to produce new words in spoken language (e.g., create a new word from masa by changing the initial sound to /p/; create a new word frompasa by changing the final sound to /o/)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish when phonemes are changed in single-syllable words to form new words (e.g., from a verbal prompt, identify that hat becomes ham)
Recognize, identify, and produce groups of words that begin with the same initial sound (i.e., alliterative words)
Manipulate phonemes one at a time to show addition, deletion, substitution, reversal, or resequencing of sounds in words or blends
With prompting and support, identify the author and illustrator of a story and explain their roles
Compare and contrast the effects of different points of view (e.g., first/third person, limited/omniscient, subjective/objective) on the plot or on the reader's perception
Describe how the narrator’s perspective influences descriptions and events in a fifth-grade literary text
Analyze how first- or third-person narration and/or multiple narrators affect a text's meaning (e.g., explain how a narrator's voice affects characterization, plot, and tone)
Describe how the speaker’s perspective influences a poem in a fifth-grade literary text
Explain who is telling a story (i.e., the first-person narrator)
Explain the different forms of third-person point of view (i.e., omniscient versus limited) used in literature
Identify the cultural perspective reflected in a work of literature from outside the United States
Identify the narrator in a story or poem told from the first person point of view
Understand that a story is told by a narrator
Identify and analyze satire, sarcasm, irony, and understatement in literary texts to explain the text's underlying meaning

Describe the narrator's or speaker's point of view in a story and how it affects the information revealed about characters and events (e.g., retell a story from the point of view of different characters)
Analyze how point of view influences the way the story is told, and how the author develops the narrator (e.g., how Robert Cormier slowly reveals the narrator's reality in I Am the Cheese)
Evaluate the influence of point of view, and analyze the effect of multiple narrators or a shifting point of view
Identify who is telling a story when prompted at different points in the text
Describe the narrator's point of view in a story and how it affects the information revealed about characters and events
Identify the cultural perspective reflected in literary works
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Recognize the difference between first- and third-person point of view
Compare and contrast the effects of different forms of narration (e.g., interior monologue, shifting points of view, ironic distance between author and narrator) across various genres of fiction
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Analyze how dramatic irony (i.e., when something is known to the audience or reader but unknown to the characters) or other devices create effects such as suspense or humor
Analyze how the use of multiple narrators affects a text
Analyze how the author develops the narrator's or character's point of view, and explain how the author's viewpoint differs from the narrator's or speaker's (e.g., unreliable narrator, irony)
Compare and contrast the narrative points of view of different stories
Analyze how the cultural perspective reflected in a work of literature from outside the United States shapes the text
Analyze the difference between the narrator's point of view and the author's implied point of view especially in a text in which there is ironic distance between the author and narrator
Analyze how point of view influences the way the story is told, and how the author develops the narrator (e.g., "La muerte de Artemio Cruz" by Carlos Fuentes o "El hombre" by Juan Rulfo)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish one character’s perspective from another's in a second-grade literary text

Explain how point of view influences the way the story is told and how the author develops the point of view of the narrator or the speaker (e.g., what the narrative descriptions reveal about the narrator)
Describe the narrator's or a character's viewpoint or opinion and distinguish it from one's own (e.g., do you agree with this character?)
Analyze how the author develops and contrasts different characters or narrators within the text (e.g., how two characters may see a situation differently)
Analyze how the author develops the narrator's point of view, and how the author's choices about point of view affect a text's meaning (e.g., use of persona, unreliable narrator, multiple narrators)
Identify the point of view (e.g., first/third person, limited/omniscient, subjective/objective)
Evaluate how a work of fiction is affected by voice, persona, and narrator
Explain the difference between first- and third-person narrative point of view

Explain the difference between first- and third-person narration (e.g., recognize whether or not the narrator is a character in the story), and compare and contrast the narrative points of view of different stories
Analyze how the cultural perspective reflected in a work of literature shapes the text
Describe the narrator of a story or the speaker of a poem
AUTHORITY: Minnesota K-12 Academic Standards in English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Analyze how the narrator's point of view and characterization affect the telling of the narrative (e.g., a biased, unreliable, or impaired first-person narrator)
Identify a character's opinions or ideas (e.g., what does Sarah think about helping in the garden?)
Acknowledge which character is speaking lines of dialogue at different points in a story (e.g., read with a different voice for different characters)
Describe how the narrator's point of view influences a third-grade story
Analyze, compare, and contrast viewpoints and purposes, both within a literary text and between literary texts
Analyze how the author develops the point of view and how it shapes a work (e.g., use of multiple narrators or a shifting point of view)
Compare the perspectives of different characters within a text
AUTHORITY: North Dakota English Language Arts Content Standards

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish between the narrator’s perspective or opinion and those of the characters in a third-grade literary text
Describe how the narrator's first-person point of view influences a second-grade literary text
Distinguish between the poet and speaker of a poem
Identify a character's opinions or ideas (e.g., ¿Qué piensa Isabel acerca de ayudar en el jardín?)
Understand the difference between the author and the narrator or speaker of a literary text (e.g., a story is written by an author and told by a narrator)
AUTHORITY: Wisconsin Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Make and check predictions by using prior knowledge, ideas from the text, text features, and obvious foreshadowing clues

Use other reading experience or prior knowledge to support simple predictions about characters and events (e.g., with support, use knowledge of books by the same author or with similar themes/settings)
Make predictions about what will happen next and confirm predictions by using key words (e.g., next, then)
Make predictions based on understanding of relationships between a series of events, ideas, and steps in an informational text
Make predictions based on the cover, title, and illustrations
Make predictions based on evidence in the text, and predict different outcomes if variables were to be changed
Recognize and join in with recurring wording and predictable phrases in stories and poems (e.g., Soplaré y soplaré, La pequeña oruga glotona, La ratita presumida)
Make predictions and locate evidence in the text to support the predictions
Make and adjust predictions based on evidence in the text (e.g., author's tone, character traits) and on prior knowledge, and explain why a prediction makes sense
Make predictions about what will happen next and confirm predictions by using key words (e.g., después, entonces)
Begin to make simple predictions about the events in an unfamiliar story read independently or heard read aloud (e.g., suggest how the story might end)
Make predictions about texts by using story repetition, transition words, and text features such as tables of contents, and explain whether the predictions were correct
Make complex predictions based on evidence in the text; connect the ideas to other texts or situations (e.g., like Hamlet, this character hesitates to act)

Analyze information given in the text to make a prediction about a related situation (e.g., apply political model to related historical event, predict character behavior based on archetypal character)
Make complex predictions based on evidence in the text; connect the ideas to other texts or situations (e.g., como el Quijote, este otro personaje se enfrenta a los problemas de la vida)
Analyze why a predicted outcome is or is not plausible by using evidence from text content and organization
Confirm or refute predictions and make adjustments by weighing information against prior experience and knowledge of the text
Recognize and join in with recurring wording and predictable phrases in stories and poems (e.g., "Sam I am" from "Green Eggs and Ham"; "I'll huff and I'll puff")
Make predictions about texts based on chapter titles, headings, tables of contents, story patterns, and relationships between events and ideas, and explain whether these predictions are correct

Make and adjust detailed predictions about content (e.g., development of ideas, topics, events, themes), author's purpose, and text organization by using prior knowledge, text features, and structure, and by previewing and questioning the text
Recognize how the spelling accent distinguishes the pronunciation of two words that are written the same (e.g., papa - papá; paso - pasó)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Understand that words are specific sequences of letters that carry meaning
Compare the lengths of different words based on how many letters they contain (e.g., explain that sit is longer than it because sit has more letters)
Identify the dialogue that quotation marks indicate
Discriminate between spoken sentences, words, and syllables
Clap and count the number of words in a given sentence
Correctly form printed letters with appropriate word and sentence spacing
Demonstrate understanding that a single syllable may also be a word (e.g., mi, me, si, su)
Recognize that a written accent (spelling accent) is a mark, called a tilde, placed above a vowel, and that the marked syllable is emphasized in pronunciation
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish between vowels and consonants and recognize that only vowels carry a written accent
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish between real and nonsense words (e.g., pick the word that is made-up: cat, dog, smu)
AUTHORITY: South Carolina College- and Career-Ready Standards English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Demonstrate some awareness of basic print concepts through activities such as pretending to read books
AUTHORITY: Pennsylvania Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Recognize one's first name in print
Develop handwriting by accurately forming all cursive letters
Correctly form printed letters and practice cursive letters with appropriate word and sentence spacing
Distinguish between similarly spelled words that have different letters (e.g., pick the word that is different from the others in: an, as, an)
Correctly form printed and cursive words with appropriate letter, word, and sentence spacing

Recognize that the written accent sometimes indicates a different meaning in words that are written with the same letters (e.g., si, sí; te, té; tu, tú), in which case it is called a diacritical accent

SKILL_NAME: Distinguish between independent and dependent clauses
Analyze in detail how a sequence of events, steps, or concepts is introduced and developed in an informational text

Follow pictorial directions such as for recipes or simple experiments

Sequence events from a story (e.g., draw pictures of events in sequence; retell beginning, middle, and end)

Analyze the order of points made in an argument to determine the connections drawn between them (e.g., implied cause and effect)

Analyze the sequence of events or ideas or steps in a process in an informational text to determine the connections drawn between them (e.g., implied cause and effect)
Recognize temporal sequence (e.g., first, next, last)

Describe the order of events or ideas from an informational text (e.g., steps in a two- or three-step process)

Describe the order of events or ideas in an informational text, recognizing and using words that show sequence (e.g., primero, siguiente, entonces)

SKILL_NAME: Investigate the context of literary texts, and draw on this knowledge to support comprehension and evaluation
Describe the setting of a story and explain why it is important

SKILL_NAME: With prompting and support, identify where a story takes place

Describe the setting and analyze how it contributes to the story

Analyze how setting influences and shapes the plot and characters

Demonstrate and apply spelling knowledge by spelling words with common patterns (e.g., CV, VC, CCV, CVC, VCV, CVCV, CCVCV, and CVCCV)
Spell two-syllable words with double-letter endings (e.g., unless, runoff)

SKILL_NAME: Spell words using grade-appropriate knowledge of stressed or accented syllables, including the schwa sound (e.g., abandon, community, terrace)

SKILL_NAME: Spell grade-appropriate words using knowledge of suffixes and how base words can change (e.g., taking, hurries, running)

Spell grade-appropriate words with y including cases in which y serves as a consonant (e.g., yet); has a long i or long e sound (e.g., dry, candy); has a short i sound (e.g., gym); or in cases in which adding an inflectional ending changes the final y to i (e.g., tried, babies)
AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Spell multisyllabic words with r-controlled syllables (e.g., perfectly)

SKILL_NAME: Spell multisyllabic words with consonant changes (e.g., /t/ in educate to /sh/ in education) and /k/ in politic to /sh/ in politician)

SKILL_NAME: Demonstrate and apply spelling knowledge by spelling words with common prefixes and suffixes
Spell multisyllabic words with VCe patterns (e.g., apologize)

Demonstrate and apply spelling knowledge by marking accents appropriately when conjugating grade-four appropriate verbs (e.g., simple and imperfect past, past participle, perfect, conditional, and future tenses)
Spell words with final /s/ sound spelled as ss, se, or ce (e.g., glass, mouse, race)

SKILL_NAME: Demonstrate and apply spelling knowledge by spelling words with the concept of diphthongs and hiatus and their implications for orthographic accents
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Demonstrate and apply spelling knowledge by spelling common letter/sound correlations
Spell grade-appropriate words using knowledge of suffixes and how base words can change, such as dropping e, changing y to i, and doubling final consonants (e.g., mistaken, flurries, trotted)
Correctly spell increasingly complex abbreviations (e.g., AZ/Arizona, mm/millimeter)
Use knowledge of grade-appropriate roots to decode and predict the meanings of unfamiliar words (e.g., actuar, reaccionar, activo, acción)

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of common foreign words (e.g., siesta, hors d'oeuvre) and phrases (e.g., faux pas, carte blanche, carpe diem) used in English
Use knowledge of second-grade prefixes and base words to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words
Use knowledge of second-grade suffixes and base words to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words

Use knowledge of grade-appropriate roots (e.g., sol-, dent-), affixes (e.g., des-, -idad), Greek, Latin, Anglo-Saxon, and Semitic sources of cognates (e.g., dentist/dentista) and patterns of how words are formed to predict the meanings or function of unfamiliar words including content-area and technical vocabulary
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Decode grade-appropriate possessive nouns in text and in isolation (e.g., wagon's, children's, boys')
Recognize formal and informal conjugations (tienes vs. tiene)
Identify and correctly apply new meanings related to already known words (e.g., know that el zapatero is the person who sells or fixes shoes)

SKILL_NAME: Decode words with diphthongs and hiatus

SKILL_NAME: Recognize and understand grade-appropriate contractions (e.g., I'm, isn't)

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of grade-appropriate affixes (e.g., ante-, multi-, -ada, -ción) and familiar base words to decode and predict the meanings of new words

SKILL_NAME: Identify the meanings of familiar base words with common inflectional forms (e.g., género -o/-a; número -os/-as, aumentativos -ote y diminutivos -ito) to read grade-appropriate words

SKILL_NAME: Read and understand grade-appropriate irregular verbs (e.g., shine/shone, slide/slid, fight/fought)

AUTHORITY: Hawai'i Common Core Standards for English Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of simple affixes (e.g., un-, re-, over-, -er, -est) and familiar base words to decode and predict the meanings of new words

Use knowledge of roots (e.g., herba, vorare), affixes (be-), cognates (e.g., Latin and Greek, Anglo-Saxon, Semitic, and other Western and non-Western sources), and patterns of how words are formed in order to predict the meaning of unfamiliar vocabulary (e.g., benign, herbivore) in a broad array of texts

Use knowledge of grade-appropriate Latin and Greek affixes (e.g., super-, infra-, ex-, il-, im-, ir-, -ivo, -ancia, -encia, -ante, -ente) and roots (e.g., gram, metro) to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words (e.g., monograma, milímetro)

SKILL_NAME: Determine the meaning of grade-appropriate compounds (e.g., bedtime, anything) by using knowledge of their component words

SKILL_NAME: With prompting and support, demonstrate understanding that a compound word is made up of two individual words (e.g., say the two words in a given compound; orally blend two words to make a familiar compound)

SKILL_NAME: Accurately read unfamiliar grade-appropriate multisyllabic words in context using knowledge of word morphology: "Mamá está de viaje y para que podamos ir al cine, nos mandó dinero. Ayer nos hizo una transferencia.")

SKILL_NAME: Accurately read unfamiliar grade-appropriate multisyllabic words in isolation, using knowledge of word morphology (e.g., autobiografía, recuerdo, perrito)

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of common foreign words (e.g., alcázar, kamikaze, tsunami) and phrases (e.g., copy/paste, back up) in Spanish and understand how they reflect historical events or developments

SKILL_NAME: Decode grade-appropriate contractions in context (e.g., I'm, we'll, it's)

SKILL_NAME: Use frequently occurring inflections (e.g., -ando, -iendo, -ió, -s, -es) and affixes with prompting and support to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words (e.g., use the inflectional ending to determine that pájaros means "más de un pájaro")

SKILL_NAME: Accurately read unfamiliar grade-appropriate multisyllabic words in context, applying greater knowledge of word morphology (e.g., read visible in a contextual sentence)

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of known words to predict the meanings of grade-appropriate compound words (e.g., downstairs, suitcase)

Recognize when a strong vowel (a, e, o) and a weak vowel (i, u) or two weak vowels form hiatus and not diphthong

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of grade-appropriate roots (e.g., surg-, surr-), affixes (e.g., de-, -idad), cognates (e.g., Latin and Greek, Anglo-Saxon, and Semitic sources), and patterns of how words are formed in order to predict the meaning of unfamiliar vocabulary (e.g., insurgente, impenetrabilidad, ajedrez)

SKILL_NAME: Accurately read unfamiliar grade-appropriate multisyllabic words in isolation, applying greater knowledge of word morphology (e.g., portar, exportar, portátil, portavoz)

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of grade-appropriate roots to decode and predict the meanings of unfamiliar words (e.g., wake and awaken)

SKILL_NAME: Compare formal and informal usage in Spanish (pronouns tú, vos, vosotros, and usted)

SKILL_NAME: Decode words with common affixes (e.g., un-, re-, over-, -er, -est) and familiar base words

SKILL_NAME: Use knowledge of grade-appropriate Latin and Greek affixes (e.g., mid-, pre-, -able, -ible, -ant, -ent, -ous, -ation) and roots to predict the meanings of unfamiliar words and content-area language (e.g., agri-/agriculture, agrarian; phon-/microphone, symphony)

Decode words with multiple sound spelling patterns such as c, k, and s, z, soft c, and x
Recognize apócope (supression or loss one or more final letters of sounds at the end of a word) in the use of adjectives (e.g., buen, bueno; gran, grande; algún, alguno; ningún, ninguno)

Use a range of strategies to determine the meanings of general academic and content-area words and phrases in grade-appropriate informational texts (e.g., beginning dictionaries; sentence-level context clues such as embedded word definitions and restatement; simple prefixes and inflections)
Determine or clarify the precise meanings of key words and phrases by using print or online glossaries or beginning dictionaries
Alphabetize a series of words to the second letter

SKILL_NAME: Use a beginning dictionary to find words by using alphabetical order
Use a dictionary or a glossary to determine the meanings, syllabication, and pronunciation of unknown words

Employ strategies to determine the meanings of general academic words and phrases in grade-appropriate literary texts, including the use of beginning dictionaries, decoding strategies, and sentence-level context clues such as word placement

Use a standard dictionary, dictionary of Spanish usage, or other specialized reference to determine the standard usage of academic words, their spellings (including diacritical marks) or to identify how usage has changed or been questioned over time (e.g., formidable: lo que es muy terrible vs. formidable: genial)
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Use a range of strategies to determine or clarify the precise meanings of general academic and content-area words and phrases in grade-appropriate informational texts more efficiently, including reference materials, affixes and roots, context clues such as word relationships, parts of speech, and the overall sentence or paragraph meaning

Determine the meanings of words and phrases in grade-appropriate texts by analyzing the impact of parts of speech (e.g., recognize verbs in the subjunctive mood to determine how they make a phrase hypothetical)
AUTHORITY: Georgia K-12 English Language Arts Standards

SKILL_NAME: Apply appropriate strategies with sophistication and independence including a broad array of context clues such as conjunctive and subordinate clauses, a variety of general or specialized reference material, and knowledge of etymology to determine, clarify, or gain greater understanding of the correct usage and nuances in meanings of general academic and content-area-specific words and phrases in grade-appropriate informational texts

Use a range of strategies to determine or clarify the precise meanings of general academic words and phrases in grade-appropriate literary texts more efficiently, including reference materials, affixes and roots, context clues such as word relationships, parts of speech, and the overall sentence or paragraph meaning

Use a dictionary or other print or online reference to clarify the meanings and spelling (including diacritical marks) of key academic or content-area words in grade-level texts, and determine or verify the part of speech based on which definition of the word fits its context
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Apply appropriate strategies with greater sophistication, including a broad array of context clues such as word relationships and connectives, a variety of general or specialized reference material, and knowledge of etymology to determine or clarify the precise meanings of general academic and content-area words and phrases in grade-appropriate informational texts

Use a range of strategies to determine or clarify the meanings of general academic words and phrases in grade-appropriate literary texts, including cause-and-effect relationships (e.g., ella le salvó la vida al niño y, por eso, fue honrada por la comunidad), comparisons (e.g., ambos personajes demostraron una perspectiva similar), Latin and Greek roots (e.g., negativo), and reference materials
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Read words aloud, correctly accenting them according to the vowel that carries the tonic accent, according to their meaning, and in context (e.g., hacia/hacía, sabia/sabía, rio/río)

SKILL_NAME: Use context to confirm or self-correct word recognition and comprehension, re-reading when necessary
AUTHORITY: Illinois Learning Standards for Spanish Language Arts

SKILL_NAME: Identify content-area vocabulary in a text (e.g., word lists, bolded terms) in order to enhance comprehension (e.g., make lists, ask for help, find definitions)

SKILL_NAME: Employ strategies to determine the meanings of general academic words and phrases in grade-appropriate informational texts, including the use of beginning dictionaries, decoding strategies, and sentence-level context clues such as word placement

SKILL_NAME: Ask and answer questions to clarify the meanings of words when listening to literary texts
